title: Quotation of the Day: Train Operator Is Killed In a Subway Car Blaze; Officials Suspect Arson
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 28, 2020.
content: “Being a motorman on a train is like being the captain of a ship. It doesn’t go down without you trying to save everyone on board.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lee Siegel
title: An Actual Virus Sobers the Goofy Age of ‘Going Viral’
description: How could we so heedlessly appropriate a medical term?
content: Virginia Woolf, laid up with the flu, wrote that: “the merest schoolgirl, when she falls in love, has Shakespeare or Keats to speak her mind for her; but let a sufferer try to describe a pain in his head to a doctor and language at once runs dry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: With Coronavirus Disrupting College, Should Every Student Pass?
description: College students across the country are pushing to abolish grades, saying the only letters that matter now are C-O-V-I-D.
content: Carlos Polanco was living in a dormitory just two weeks ago, taking classes and thinking mostly about getting good grades and life after graduation. Now he is back in Clifton, N.J., home schooling his 12-year-old sister, doing household chores and worrying about the health of his relatives in the Dominican Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner and Corinne Purtill
title: Figuring Out Home Schooling in the Age of Coronavirus
description: Two journalists, with five children between them, discuss what life is like with schools closed and kids at home.
content: — Corinne Purtill, a Los Angeles-based journalist who covers health, science and technology
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: 6 Killed in House Fire in Rural Indiana, Officials Say
description: Officials are investigating the cause of a fire that destroyed a family home and killed six people early Saturday morning.
content: Six people were left dead in a fire that destroyed a family home in rural Indiana early Saturday morning, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Covid-19 Brings Out All the Usual Zombies
description: Why virus denial resembles climate denial.
content: Let me summarize the Trump administration/right-wing media view on the coronavirus: It’s a hoax, or anyway no big deal. Besides, trying to do anything about it would destroy the economy. And it’s China’s fault, which is why we should call it the “Chinese virus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Buruma
title: Virus as Metaphor
description: There’s a long history of illness being used to stoke hatred. We cannot succumb to it now.
content: President Trump and some of his allies have made a point of calling the coronavirus a “Chinese virus,” the “Wuhan virus” or, simply, a “foreign virus.” Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas even suggested the Chinese had devised the virus as a biological weapon. They would like us to believe that the disease is like a foreign invasion, an alien attack on the people of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Marc Stein
title: They Celebrated Basketball and a Birthday. Then Came Coronavirus.
description: A tight social circle bound by New York City basketball is hit hard by Covid-19, with two dead and others ailing.
content: The connections in New York City basketball run deep. Generations of boys and young men starred on the playgrounds, the school courts, on the AAU circuit. If you did not play with someone, you probably played against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Bring in the Robot Cleaners: Travel Industry Innovations for the Pandemic
description: “Private” hotels, online tour-company teasers for future travelers, and other ways that travel companies are keeping their businesses alive.
content: While most hotels that remain open after the outbreak of Covid-19 are stepping up cleaning routines, the Westin Houston Medical Center in Houston, Texas, is going beyond Lysol and bleach. In addition to standard cleaning protocols, it says it is the first to deploy two newly acquired robots to sanitize rooms and common areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: A Box of Secrets Led to the Story of Her Father’s Painful Wartime Past
description: Ariana Neumann’s father had nightmares and an ID card in a different name. In her memoir, “When Time Stopped,” she unspools the past he kept hidden for so long.
content: WHEN TIME STOPPED A Memoir of My Father’s War and What RemainsBy Ariana Neumann
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: National Enquirer Publisher Is Cutting Employees’ Pay
description: American Media is the latest media outlet to announce cuts as the coronavirus has shaken the economy and the advertising market.
content: American Media Inc., the publisher of The National Enquirer, Men’s Journal, Us Weekly and other titles, is cutting the pay of its employees by more than 20 percent, a spokesman said on Saturday, as the coronavirus has shaken the economy and the advertising market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Ray Mantilla, Percussionist Who Transcended Genres, Dies at 85
description: He was adept at a range of instruments, particularly the congas and timbales, and he could make himself at home in almost any ensemble.
content: Ray Mantilla, a percussionist and bandleader whose career spanned six decades and an array of styles in jazz, Latin music and beyond, died on March 21 in Manhattan. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Finding Comfort in a Bottle of Familiar Wine
description: In times of fear and anxiety, we find solace in foods that conjure up memories and emotions. Why not wines?
content: Like so many others, my wife and I have been self-isolating in our apartment, doing our best to stay close to our loved ones from afar, and cooking the foods that we find most comforting: split-pea soup, various bean dishes, spaghetti and meatballs, just for starters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: ‘We are Trying to Protect Our Own’: The Towns Keeping Part-Timers Out
description: Defenders of property rights find something else they want to defend: Their own communities.
content: John Lowry vacationed in Door County, Wis., when he was a child. He loved it so much that 30 years ago he moved there. It’s not in his nature to tell people who share his fondness for what he calls “the Cape Cod of the Midwest” to please just stay away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Najim Rahim
title: Taliban Attack Afghanistan Amid Growing Coronavirus Threat
description: Insurgents launched major assaults as preparations continued for a prisoner exchange and as diplomats worked to revive the peace plan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban on Saturday attacked several provinces in northern Afghanistan, overrunning large parts of one district even as American diplomats expressed optimism that a peace process stalled over the release of prisoners was getting back on track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: A Unanimous Senate Vote That Nobody Seemed to Agree On
description: Lawmakers unanimously approved a historic government aid package, but the debate was vicious.
content: WASHINGTON — After a four-year stretch marked by an acrimonious fight over a Supreme Court vacancy, the poisonous Kavanaugh confirmation and a bitter impeachment trial, was it too much to hope that a global health and economic crisis could suddenly rid the Senate of its own partisan infection?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey, Megan Janetsky and Andrea Zarate
title: Doctor, Refugee. Violinist, Refugee. Model, Refugee.
description: They felt on top of the world. Then the world turned upside down.
content: When earthquake, war or social upheaval drives you across a border and into the unknown, you learn the hard lesson of the refugee: You didn’t just lose a home, a job, a country. You may also have lost your identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Smith
title: What Shakespeare Teaches Us About Living With Pandemics
description: Plague erased social, gender and personal differences. Shakespeare responded by emphasizing people’s unique and inerasable difference. His work is a narrative vaccine.
content: OXFORD, England — Twitter has been taunting us: When he was in quarantine from the plague, William Shakespeare wrote “King Lear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin
title: Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, Civil Rights Leader and King Aide, Dies at 98
description: Mr. Lowery helped found the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and gave the benediction at President Barack Obama’s inauguration.
content: The Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, a lieutenant to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who helped organize a pivotal moment in the civil rights movement — the bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala. — and who gave the benediction at President Barack Obama’s inauguration more than half a century later, died on Friday at his home in Atlanta. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia
title: U.S. Cuts Health Care Aid to Yemen Despite Worries About Coronavirus
description: The Trump administration cited interference by Houthi rebels. But humanitarian groups and some Democrats asked for a delay because of the pandemic.
content: The Trump administration on Friday cut off tens of millions of dollars for health care programs and other aid in Yemen, rejecting pleas by humanitarian groups and some members of Congress to delay the decision as the coronavirus spreads across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey, Megan Janetsky and Andrea Zarate
title: Doctor, Refugee. Violinist, Refugee. Model, Refugee.
description: They felt on top of the world. Then the world turned upside down.
content: When earthquake, war or social upheaval drives you across a border and into the unknown, you learn the hard lesson of the refugee: You didn’t just lose a home, a job, a country. You may also have lost your identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 4-Year-Old Girl, Lost in the Woods for 48 Hours, Is Found Unharmed
description: “Ecstatic may not be a good enough word — it was extremely emotional,” Sheriff Jay Jones of Lee County, Ala., said of finding Evelyn Sides, better known as Vadie.
content: Evelyn Sides, better known as Vadie, and her dog Lucy were playing in the backyard of a family friend’s house on Wednesday when they suddenly wandered off into the deep Alabama woods. When the friend who had been watching 4-year-old Vadie realized she was missing, she called 911.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel
title: We Can Safely Restart the Economy in June. Here’s How.
description: Get tough now. Test widely to isolate those infected, and slowly revive businesses with workers and customers who have developed immunity.
content: The argument that harsh restrictions on business and social interaction during the Covid-19 pandemic will do more harm than good has real power. Unemployment is projected to rise to 30 percent in a few months, and an economic contraction in the second quarter of 15 percent or more has been forecast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
title: Panic Buying Comes for the Seeds
description: I’m clearly not the only one who is desperate to garden.
content: On a recent Sunday, after I’d completed my push-up challenge, counted my rolls of toilet paper and sketched out a new work-from-home schedule that I would eventually abandon by midday Monday, I looked online in search of something that my pandemic-addled mind had decided overnight was essential: seeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Michael D. Shear
title: The U.S.’s Slow Start to Coronavirus Testing: A Timeline
description: Technical flaws, regulatory hurdles and failures of leadership impeded early screening in the United States, allowing the pandemic to spread.
content: The World Health Organization says that Chinese health officials in Wuhan revealed a “cluster of cases of pneumonia of unknown cause.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Captain Phillips’ and ‘Fly Away Home’
description: A thriller starring Tom Hanks airs on SundanceTV. And a family drama with Jeff Daniels comes to Criterion.
content: CAPTAIN PHILLIPS (2013) 9 p.m. on SundanceTV. Directed by Paul Greengrass, who quickened the pace of several Bourne franchise movies, “Captain Phillips” is fraught with urgency. It’s a thriller — enhanced by its basis in true events — about an American cargo ship captain whose vessel is taken over by Somali pirates. The captain, Richard Phillips, is played by Tom Hanks, who “can convey a sense of old-fashioned American decency just by standing in the frame,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. But underneath the plot’s fast-paced action and Phillips’s all-American heroism, the movie succeeds in its humanization of the Somalis, providing “an unsettling look at global capitalism and American privilege and power,” Dargis wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: The New Rules of Running Now
description: It’s difficult to balance the risks of exercising outside against the benefits.
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Analyzing the Patterns in Trump’s Falsehoods About Coronavirus
description: For months, the president has downplayed the severity of the pandemic, overstated the impact of his policies and potential treatments, blamed others and tried to rewrite the history of his response.
content: Hours after the United States became the nation with the largest number of reported coronavirus cases on Thursday, President Trump appeared on Fox News and expressed doubt about shortages of medical supplies, boasted about the country’s testing capacity, and criticized his predecessor’s response to an earlier outbreak of a different disease.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eat Cake for Breakfast!
description: This week’s popular dishes, including pasta e ceci and no-knead bread.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Melissa Clark’s recipe for pantry crumb cake (above); roasted potatoes with anchovies and tuna; and Mark Bittman’s no-knead bread. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood and Damon Winter
title: When the Mundane Becomes Heroic
description: These are the people still working on a single block in Manhattan.
content: On March 20, in an effort to control the growing number of coronavirus cases in New York — New York City in particular — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo issued an executive order requiring all nonessential businesses to keep their workers at home. Restaurants, grocery stores, pharmacies, convenience stores and hardware stores are all deemed essential, and all are allowed to remain open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood and Damon Winter
title: When the Mundane Becomes Heroic
description: These are the people still working on a single block in Manhattan.
content: On March 20, in an effort to control the growing number of coronavirus cases in New York — New York City in particular — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo issued an executive order requiring all nonessential businesses to keep their workers at home. Restaurants, grocery stores, pharmacies, convenience stores and hardware stores are all deemed essential, and all are allowed to remain open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: A Wall. A Ball. That’s All: Your New Social-Distancing Workout
description: Long-ignored vertical slabs all over the city are having a moment.
content: In a park along the Hudson River in Manhattan’s Battery Park City, New Yorkers are queuing up — six feet apart, of course — for their turn to play with a wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: The Nordic Way to Economic Rescue
description: In the face of the pandemic, Denmark is effectively nationalizing private payrolls, in contrast to the patchwork American system.
content: The unleashing of cash by Congress to combat the catastrophe of the pandemic amounts to the traditional American prescription — in gargantuan form. The $2 trillion package of spending expands the standard unemployment insurance system, while setting aside a pool of money that is supposed to aid distressed companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Pandemic Mars Putin’s Coronation and Endangers Russia’s Veterans
description: President Vladimir Putin’s grand plans to celebrate the 75th anniversary of victory in World War II, and his own leadership, may be foiled by the coronavirus, which also threatens war heroes.
content: MOSCOW — When local officials bearing flowers and a medal arrived to pay tribute to a 93-year-old grandmother and war veteran at her home north of Moscow, they didn’t get quite the welcome they expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Frightened by Coronavirus, Many of U.K.’s Poles Are Heading Home
description: They say the government’s slow response and a creaking health service contrast poorly with Poland’s health system and aggressive actions. The epidemic also put many of them out of work.
content: LONDON — As the coronavirus epidemic gathered pace, Jaroslaw Bacdorf agonized over whether to stay in London, where he has lived and worked for eight years, or head back to Poland to join his wife, children and mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: U.S. Civil Rights Office Rejects Rationing Medical Care Based on Disability, Age
description: Medical providers must not engage in “ruthless utilitarianism” in deciding who gets lifesaving treatment for the coronavirus, a federal civil rights officer warned.
content: The director of the federal health department’s civil rights office said on Saturday that his office was opening a series of civil rights investigations to ensure that states did not allow medical providers to discriminate on the basis of disabilities, race, age or certain other factors when deciding who would receive lifesaving medical care during the coronavirus emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Says a Quarantine ‘Will Not Be Necessary’
description: At least 17 states reported tallies of at least 1,000 infections. Illinois reported the first known U.S. death of an infant with the virus.
content: This briefing has ended. Read live updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Backtracks After Cuomo Criticizes Quarantine Idea
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo compared the president’s suggestion that he was considering a quarantine on the New York region to “a declaration of war on states.”
content: President Trump backtracked on Saturday night after earlier in the day floating the possibility of imposing an “enforceable” travel quarantine on the New York region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Javier C. Hernández
title: Coronavirus Crisis Awakens a Sleeping Giant: China’s Youth
description: How the ruling Communist Party manages the coming months will help shape how hundreds of millions of young people see its authoritarian political bargain for decades to come.
content: Students have flooded social media to organize donations for Chinese doctors battling the coronavirus epidemic. Workers have marched in the streets to demand compensation for weeks of unemployment during citywide lockdowns. Young citizen journalists have taken to YouTube to call for free speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Instacart Shoppers Plan to Strike Over Coronavirus Protections
description: As many as 200,000 workers could walk off the job unless demands for improved equipment and hazard pay are met.
content: Employees of Instacart, a tech company that delivers groceries and other household items ordered through an app, plan a nationwide strike on Monday, maintaining that the company has not provided them with supplies to protect them from being infected during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Strangers in an Empty Dorm
description: The couple met as students a week before classes began at Grinnell College in 2009. He was there early for a canoe trip; she was a student adviser.
content: Andrew Platt answered the knock on his dormitory door a week before classes began at Grinnell College in August 2009. He found Sarah Mayer standing there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Maggie Astor
title: Grappling With the Impact of Coronavirus: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Joe Biden tries to break through, Bernie Sanders signals he’s staying in and another Super Tuesday (of sorts) emerges.
content: Hello, from the socially distanced land of our comfy (read: tiny) New York apartments!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Infinite Visions Were Hiding in the First Black Hole Image’s Rings
description: Scientists proposed a technique that would allow us to see more of the unseeable.
content: A year ago a team of radio astronomers startled the world with the first photograph of a black hole, lurking like the eye of Sauron in the heart of a distant galaxy. Now it appears there was more hiding in that image than we had imagined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: They Survived the Spanish Flu, the Depression and the Holocaust
description: Two extraordinary women — one 101, the other 95 — lived through the worst of the 20th century. They have some advice for you.
content: For most of us, it is almost impossible to comprehend the ferocity and regularity with which life was upended during the first half of the 20th century. Plague and conflict emerged on an epic scale, again and again. Loss and restriction were routine; disaster was its own season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Larry Kramer, AIDS Warrior, Takes on Another Plague
description: As his onetime foe and current friend, Dr. Anthony Fauci, confronts the coronavirus, the writer and activist watches history repeat itself.
content: Larry Kramer, the AIDS activist who became that epidemic’s wrathful prophet, is now writing a play for the age of Covid-19, perhaps the last work he will ever write.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Craft
title: No Fan of Sports, a Graphic Novelist Learns to Follow the Bouncing Ball
description: In “Dragon Hoops,” Gene Luen Yang intercuts the thrilling wins and crushing losses of one high school team with basketball’s own turbulent history.
content: Like “American Born Chinese” — his groundbreaking 2006 Y.A. debut, and the first graphic novel to be a finalist for the National Book Award — Gene Luen Yang’s DRAGON HOOPS (First Second, 446 pp., $24.99; ages 14 to 18) weaves multiple story lines of American identity and anxiety into a comics format.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Price Gouging Complaints Surge Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
description: Prosecutors across the country are investigating exorbitant price increases on hand sanitizer, disinfectant wipes and masks as well as everyday grocery items like chicken, rice and milk.
content: In Florida, one seller was offering 15 N95 face masks on Amazon — for $3,799.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Cuomo Postpones New York’s Primary Election to June 23 Because of Coronavirus
description: New York became the latest state to move its primary in an attempt to limit the risk of spreading the virus.
content: New York will postpone its April 28 presidential primary until June 23, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Saturday, buying time for the state to administer an election as it struggles to respond to the escalating coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Looking for Hope, Uplift or Just a Distraction From Virus Fears? Read On.
description: It’s grim out there. But in music, messages of hope — and goofy stuff online — people are trying to provide ways to get through a scary time.
content: ATLANTA — Neighbors have shared messages of togetherness etched on sidewalks in chalk. Performers have shared their music. Restaurants have shared their food, handing out free meals and giving the homeless a place to dine together, just as long as they stayed six feet apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: Germany Has Relatively Few Deaths From Coronavirus. Why?
description: The country is not immune to the pandemic. So what explains its current low fatality rate?
content: BERLIN — Europe is in crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Who Killed Keylan Knapp?
description: My childhood friend has joined America’s “deaths of despair.”
content: Among the kids who boarded my No. 6 school bus each morning near Yamhill, Ore., were the Knapps, five smart and rambunctious children whose family had recently bought their first home and were full of confidence in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, !!? — #%&?!!
content: ACROSTIC — I assume that I’m not alone in feeling shellshocked by today’s puzzle, like finding out that the bus driver you say hello to every morning is actually a Formula One driver when she is called upon to cut off a fleeing vehicle on the highway. One minute you’re settling in for your pleasant regular commute, the next you’re holding on for dear life trying to make sense of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump Suggests He Can Gag Inspector General for Stimulus Bailout Program
description: In a signing statement, the president undermined a key safeguard Democrats had insisted upon as a condition of approving $500 billion in corporate relief in the $2 trillion law.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump signed the $2 trillion economic stabilization package on Friday to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, he undercut a crucial safeguard that Democrats insisted upon as a condition of agreeing to include a $500 billion corporate bailout fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Instacart Shoppers Plan to Strike Over Coronavirus Protections
description: As many as 200,000 workers could walk off the job unless demands for improved equipment and hazard pay are met.
content: Employees of Instacart, a tech company that delivers groceries and other household items ordered through an app, plan a nationwide strike on Monday, maintaining that the company has not provided them with supplies to protect them from being infected during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
title: Parents Work on the Front Lines. Where Do Their Children Go All Day?
description: An experimental program attempts to fill the void of shuttered public schools.
content: Though New York City public schools are closed, 9-year-old Trayvon Lee spent the day inside a school building on West 93rd Street in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Rhode Island Pulls Over New Yorkers to Keep the Virus at Bay
description: Police and National Guard troops are deployed to warn visitors they must self-quarantine, as local resentment builds toward people fleeing coronavirus hot spots.
content: Police officers were watching Rhode Island’s highways, bridges and bus stops. National Guard troops were trudging through resort towns with clipboards, knocking on doors. They were all hunting for fleeing New Yorkers and their telltale Empire State license plates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle and Christina Caron
title: ‘Women Will Not Be Forced to Be Alone When They Are Giving Birth’
description: In response to some private hospitals’ decision to bar partners, New York will order all hospitals to allow partners in delivery rooms, despite the coronavirus risk.
content: Women preparing to give birth at some hospitals in New York City will no longer have to labor alone,  state officials said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: FEMA Says at Least 7 People at the Disaster Agency Have the Coronavirus
description: Union officials at FEMA say they would like to know where they work in order to warn other employees who might  be exposed and to avoid putting the public at added risk.
content: WASHINGTON — The agency leading the nation’s coronavirus response said that seven of its employees had tested positive for the virus with another four cases pending, though in a letter to its employees’ union, it declined a request to say where they were located, prompting criticism from the union that the agency was jeopardizing public health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Clifford Krauss and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian State Oil Company Rosneft, in Sudden Move, Sells Assets in Venezuela
description: The U.S. had imposed sanctions on two Rosneft oil trading subsidiaries this year for helping Venezuela’s authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro.
content: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Russian state-controlled oil firm Rosneft said Saturday it was ceasing operations in Venezuela and selling all of its assets in the country, signaling a shift in Kremlin strategy that could further rattle Venezuela’s crumbling economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Abby Goodnough, Sheila Kaplan, Sheri Fink, Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
title: The Lost Month: How a Failure to Test Blinded the U.S. to Covid-19
description: Aggressive screening might have helped contain the coronavirus in the United States. But technical flaws, regulatory hurdles and lapses in leadership let it spread undetected for weeks.
content: WASHINGTON — Early on, the dozen federal officials charged with defending America against the coronavirus gathered day after day in the White House Situation Room, consumed by crises. They grappled with how to evacuate the United States consulate in Wuhan, China, ban Chinese travelers and extract Americans from the Diamond Princess and other cruise ships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Tom Coburn, the ‘Dr. No’ of Congress, Is Dead at 72
description: His prolific use of a bill-blocking measure earned him his nickname, but he also won grudging respect on Capitol Hill as a political maverick.
content: Tom Coburn, an ultraconservative Oklahoma Republican and family physician who in 16 years in Congress crusaded for limited government, using a rule-book technicality to block so many bills that frustrated legislators called him “Dr. No,” died on Saturday in Tulsa. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Sheera Frenkel
title: Medical Expert Who Corrects Trump Is Now a Target of the Far Right
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the administration’s most outspoken advocate of emergency virus measures, faces a torrent of false claims that he is mobilizing to undermine the president.
content: At a White House briefing on the coronavirus on March 20, President Trump called the State Department the “Deep State Department.” Behind him, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, dropped his head and rubbed his forehead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: In the Coronavirus Fight in Scandinavia, Sweden Stands Apart
description: The country has drawn global attention with an unorthodox approach while its neighbors have imposed extensive restrictions.
content: STOCKHOLM — When the coronavirus swept into the Scandinavian countries, Norway and Denmark scrambled to place extensive restrictions on their borders to stem the outbreak. Sweden, their neighbor, took a decidedly different path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tove Danovich
title: America Stress-Bought All the Baby Chickens
description: In times of anxiety, we hoard the sources of eggs.
content: For chicken hatcheries, the weeks leading up to Easter are always the busiest. Spring is in the air for people shaking off long winters spent watching Netflix under a blanket who had hoped to emerge into a world of budding flowers, green grass and baby animals.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 28, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 28, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about public health experts’ plea to the federal government to take over the nation’s ventilator supply referred imprecisely to a study’s estimate of the need for ventilators in the United States. The study, by the Society of Critical Care Medicine, projected that there may be as many as one million people in the United States who need treatment with a ventilator over the course of the pandemic, not that the country will need 1 million ventilators over the course of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Race/Related: Covid-19 and the Collapse of America’s Welfare State
description: “In the United States, people are supposed to survive on their own. Those who cannot, are often left to sink.”
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Dharisha Bastians
title: As Pandemic Rages, Sri Lanka’s President Pardons a War Criminal
description: Rights groups accused President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of taking advantage of the global chaos to free a soldier convicted of killing civilians.
content: Sri Lanka’s president has pardoned a soldier who was sentenced to death for killing eight civilians during the country’s civil war, leading to accusations that the government was taking advantage of the chaos from the coronavirus pandemic to free a wartime ally accused of atrocities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Young Deal With the Coronavirus
description: High school and college students urge their cohort to take the threat seriously, and adults reassure the young that past adversities and uncertainties have been overcome.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Coronavirus May Add Billions to the Nation’s Health Care Bill
description: Insurance premiums could spike as much as 40 percent next year, a new analysis warns, as employers and insurers confront the projected tens of billions of dollars in additional costs of treating coronavirus patients.
content: With so much still uncertain about how widespread hospitalizations for coronavirus patients will be around the United States, a new analysis says premiums could increase as much as 40 percent next year if the pandemic results in millions of Americans needing hospital stays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Some Choice Words
description: Saturday, again? Erik Agard stays the deadpan course.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The first word of the first clue of the puzzle today made me think “Aw, yeah, it’s Erik Agard.” One of my high school professors had a placard on his desk, à la President Truman’s “the buck stops here,” that said “Eschew obfuscation.” He was wickedly sharp, and always prepared to handle any of our angsty, teenage nonsense with good-natured dry humor that always settled things down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Silent Spring Is Saying Something
description: The eerie inhumanity of Donald Trump.
content: This is the silent spring. The planet has gone quiet, so quiet you can almost hear it whirling around the sun, feel its smallness, picture for once the loneliness and fleetingness of being alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Keep the Change
description: Ricky Cruz’s Sunday debut rewards scrutiny.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Ricky Cruz is 22 years old and this is his second puzzle for The Times this month, as well as his first Sunday grid. As Will Shortz says in the print introduction, Mr. Cruz is a video game concept artist, creating detailed environments for 3-D games; this is his attempt to turn a crossword “into a fun visual experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: New Orleans Restaurants, Used to Disasters, Reckon With Something Worse
description: The dining and bar scene, so central to the city’s identity, emerged strong from Hurricane Katrina. But the coronavirus crisis is different.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Tommy Tommaseo is not nostalgic for Hurricane Katrina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Clark
title: The Healing Power of ‘Steven Universe’
description: The hit cartoon series has helped me process my biracial identity.
content: For most of my life, Taiwan was a place that lived in my head. My mother told me her origin stories like a series of tall tales, full of pitched, tin roofs and fields of underbrush that my grandmother used to drive through on her moped, lifting her legs to avoid snake bites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Rational Panic, but Also Rational Hope
description: We need to recognize any signposts leading up and out.
content: For far too long, America’s response to the coronavirus lacked what you might call rational panic. From the experts to the markets to the president and his cable-television court, an irrational calm prevailed when a general freak-out might have prepared us for the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Tornado Strikes Jonesboro, Ark., Injuring at Least 6, Official Says
description: An airport, a shopping mall and various local businesses were damaged.
content: A tornado cut through the heart of Jonesboro, Ark., on Saturday evening, injuring at least six people and damaging a mall, local business and an airport, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Sabrina Ionescu’s Big Moment Wasn’t the One She Expected
description: The Oregon star had been called “the puppet oligarch” by Kobe Bryant, but faced tragedy and canceled games in what was supposed to be a dream college season.
content: EUGENE, Ore. — Sabrina Ionescu woke not long after dawn in her small apartment, laced up her black Nikes and walked across a deserted street to the looming arena where she had spent the last four years creating memories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Matthew Rosenberg and Edward Wong
title: As Virus Spreads, China and Russia See Openings for Disinformation
description: The two powers amplify discredited conspiracy theories and sow division as they look to undermine the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — China and Russia have both seized on the novel coronavirus to wage disinformation campaigns that seek to sow doubts about the United States’ handling of the crisis and deflect attention from their own struggles with the pandemic, according to American intelligence officials and diplomats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Annie Karni
title: Trump to Issue Travel Advisory for N.Y. Region, Backing Off Quarantine Threat
description: The suggestion of a quarantine, which would have been a drastic exercise of power, drew swift condemnation and surprised top officials in the area.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Saturday night that he would not impose a quarantine on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, but would instead issue a “strong” travel advisory for the region to be enacted by the governors of the three states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: N.Y.C.’s 911 System Is Overwhelmed. ‘I’m Terrified,’ a Paramedic Says.
description: With coronavirus cases mounting, emergency workers are making life-or-death decisions about who goes to a hospital, and who is left behind.
content: The first of many calls that night involved a 24-year-old man who had a fever, body aches and a cough that sounded like a cement mixer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Tokyo Olympics Organizers Considering July 2021 for Opening Ceremony
description: The 2020 Summer Games, postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic, would start July 23, 2021, under a plan organizers are considering.
content: LONDON — The Summer Olympics in Tokyo, postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic, will likely open on July 23, 2021, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty and Ben Casselman
title: April Bills Loom. The Economy Hangs on How Many Are Left Unpaid.
description: With businesses and personal finances hit hard by a loss of income, the first of the month may mean triage in deciding what to pay.
content: On Wednesday, as on the first day of any month, many companies and households will have bills to pay. This time, a lot will simply pile up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Matthew Rosenberg and Edward Wong
title: As Virus Spreads, China and Russia See Openings for Disinformation
description: The two powers amplify discredited conspiracy theories and sow division as they look to undermine the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — China and Russia have both seized on the novel coronavirus to wage disinformation campaigns that seek to sow doubts about the United States’ handling of the crisis and deflect attention from their own struggles with the pandemic, according to American intelligence officials and diplomats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch, Terry Ratzlaff and Darrell Woolsey
title: Alone on the Road, a Trucker’s Long Haul as America Fights the Virus
description: Darrell Woolsey does not know when he will go home to Wyoming and his wife and three children.
content: Like so many other long-haul truckers, pumping wares of a gasping economy through the arteries of the nation’s highway system, Darrell Woolsey sees the changing landscape through his windshield.
source.name: The New York Times
